name: Visual representations of adding and subtracting within 100

explanations.A: How many sticks are there altogether in the top picture? How many blocks?
explanations.B: Each stick is 10, and each block is 1. In total in the calculation we have 5 sticks and 12 blocks. 10 of the blocks make another stick of 10, so then we have 6 sticks and 2 blocks.
explanations.C: You have subtracted the blocks, but the question asks you to add them. How many sticks are there altogether in the top picture? How many blocks?
explanations.D: How many sticks are there altogether in the top picture? How many blocks? Remember that 10 blocks makes a stick of 10.

explanations.A: You have subtracted the blocks, but the question asks you to add them. How many sticks are there altogether in the top picture? How many blocks?
explanations.B: Not quite. Count the number of blocks again. There are 8 in the first picture and 6 in the second. How many would this be altogether?
explanations.C: How many sticks are there altogether in the top picture? How many blocks? Remember that 10 blocks makes a stick of 10.
explanations.D: Each stick is 10, and each block is 1. In total in the calculation we have 3 sticks and 14 blocks. 10 of the blocks make another stick of 10, so then we have 4 sticks and 4 blocks.

explanations.A: 3 ones add 4 ones gives 7 ones, and 3 tens add 2 tens gives 5 tens, giving us a total of 5 tens and 7 ones, which in digits is written as 57.
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you have mixed up your digits. In a 2-digit number, your tens digit is the first number, and your ones digit is the second number.
explanations.C: Be careful when writing your answer and make sure you use place value columns. Remember it is units on the right, and then tens to the left of that. We can only have one digit in each column.
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you counted your starting number when adding on. So when adding 2 to 3, remember it's 4, 5.

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you counted your starting number when adding on. So when adding 3 on to 4, remember it's 5, 6, 7.
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you have mixed up your digits. In a 2-digit number, your tens digit is the first number, and your ones digit is the second number.
explanations.C: Be careful when writing your answer and make sure you use place value columns. Remember it is units on the right, and then tens to the left of that. We can only have one digit in each column.
explanations.D: 2 ones add 4 ones gives 6 ones, and 4 tens add 3 tens gives 7 tens, giving us a total of 7 tens and 6 ones, which in digits is written as 76.

explanations.A: Not quite; you must take away the digits that have the same place value. Here, we have 6 tens, and we need to take away 3 tens.
explanations.B: 7 ones take away 2 ones gives 5 ones, and 6 tens take away 3 tens gives 3 tens, giving us a total of 3 tens and 5 ones, which in digits is written as 35.
explanations.C: Not quite; I think you have mixed up the digits in your answer. In a 2-digit number, your tens digit is the first number, and your ones digit is the second number.
explanations.D: Not quite; I think you added. James has been asked to subtract 32 from 67.

explanations.A: 9 ones take away 3 ones gives 6 ones, and 5 tens take away 2 tens gives 3 tens, giving us a total of 3 tens and 6 ones, which in digits is written as 36.
explanations.B: Not quite; you must take away the digits that have the same place value. Here, we have 5 tens, and we need to take away 2 tens.
explanations.C: Not quite; I think you have mixed up the digits in your answer. In a 2-digit number, your tens digit is the first number, and your ones digit is the second number.
explanations.D: Not quite; I think you added. Claire has been asked to subtract 23 from 59.

explanations.A: Not quite; I think you added. We have been asked to subtract 24 from 63.
explanations.B: Not quite; you must take away the digits that have the same place value. Remember we can exchange a 10 stick for 10 ones if needed.
explanations.C: I think you took away the 2 tens and 3 ones, but then added in an extra one rather than taking an extra one away. Taking away the 3 ones shown means we haven't taken away enough; we need to take away 1 more. This can be taken from a 10-stick.
explanations.D: As 4 ones cannot be taken away from 3 ones, we must exchange 1 stick of 10 for 10 ones. This means 63 has been partitioned into 5 tens and 13 ones. 13 ones take away 4 ones gives 9 ones, and 5 tens take away 2 tens gives 3 tens, giving us a total of 3 tens and 9 ones, which in digits is written as 39.

explanations.A: Not quite, I think you've added. We've been asked to subtract 37 from 84.
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you made a mistake when subtracting the 7 units from 4. Remember you may need to exchange one stick of 10 for 10 ones.
explanations.C: Not quite; you must take away the digits that have the same place value. Remember we can exchange a 10 stick for 10 ones if needed.
explanations.D: Dealing with the ones first, we cannot take away 7 ones, so we need to exchange one of the 10 sticks for 10 ones; we now have 14 ones. Taking 7 away from the 14 leaves us with 7. Now I need to subtract the 3 ten sticks from the remaining 7, leaving me with 4. That means we have 4 tens and 7 ones, which is 47.

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you made the tens the same, and then made the units the same, but this meant you added too many. Make the units the same first, and then see how many tens you need to add.
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you made the answer up to 4 ten sticks, but you still need some unit cubes.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you tried to add the sticks on, but you haven't taken into account the units. Try making the units match first, and then move onto the tens.
explanations.D: To make the units match we need to add on 4 to make a stick, and then another 3, so 7 cubes in total. Now we have an extra stick made of unit cubes, we only need one more. That means we added on 1 stick and 7 cubes.

explanations.A: To make the units match we need to add on 6 to make a stick, and then another 1, so 7 cubes in total. Now we have an extra stick made of unit cubes, we only need 3 more. That means we added on 3 sticks and 7 cubes.
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you made the answer up to 6 ten sticks, but you still need some unit cubes.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you tried to add the sticks on, but you haven't taken into account the units. Try making the units match first, and then move onto the tens.
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you made the tens the same, and then made the units the same, but this meant you added too many. Make the units the same first, and then see how many tens you need to add.
